awd_titl_txt: Parasitism's Impact During the Cyclic Decline of a Snowshoe Hare Population
awd_abstract_narration: This research involves a field experiment that will                        determine the impact of helminth parasitism on a cyclic snowshoe                hare population during its first 2 years of decline from peak                   abundance.  The overwinter food shortage and intense predation                  that typically occur at this stage of the hare cycle, together                  with major demographic changes, provide a unique opportunity to                 test hypotheses about parasitism's interaction with malnutrition                and predation.                                                                       The field experiment entails a 2 x 2 factoral design with                  three replicates.  Each replicate consists of food-added and                    food-normal treatments within which the demographic attributes                  (survival, reproduction, movements, etc.) of parasite-free and                  parasite-normal cohorts will be monitored through radio                         telemetry.  Pilot studies have demonstrated our ability to purge                gastrointestinal helminths and lungworms from snowshoe hares in                 the wild and to assess proximate cause of death of radio-collard                hares.  The project will test long-standing theory or factors                   controlling population aples in vertebrate species.
